awd_titl_txt: CC* Regional: A Purpose-built SoCal Science DMZ for Catalyzing Scientific Research Collaborations
awd_abstract_narration:
The Los Nettos Regional Network is a long-standing regional research and education (R&E) network with a history of supporting science and engineering research for its more than 30 members and associates in the greater Los Angeles area. This project builds a friction-free regional Science DMZ network across multiple Southern California college campuses, catalyzing collaborative research capabilities at the institutions. The project establishes the network infrastructure and software necessary to facilitate high speed transfers of large-scale research data for regional and national scientific collaborations. The campuses included in the network are Loyola Marymount University, Occidental College, and The Claremont Colleges consortium, which consists of Claremont Graduate University, Claremont McKenna College, Harvey Mudd College, Keck Graduate Institute, Pitzer College, Pomona College, and Scripps College. 

This purpose-built science network is specially customized for each institution’s unique needs and follows the well-known Science DMZ guidelines established by ESnet. The new network interconnects with state, national, and international networks, such as CENIC’s California Research and Education Network (CalREN), Internet2, and Pacific Wave. Many projects in various science domains benefit from the significant network capacity increase that this project supports. Coordinated activities at the regional level, including technical training for administrators and researchers at each campus, ensure uniform standards are maintained. This scalable R&E network can be expanded in the future for researchers and students at other smaller regional institutions (e.g., Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science, ArtCenter College of Design) as their need for collaboration widens.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to create a dedicated research network for under-resourced smaller colleges in Southern California, enabling researchers and scientists at these institutions to conduct their research more effectively and collaborate regionally and nationally. Through a partnership with Claremont Colleges, Loyola Marymount University, and Occidental College, Los Nettos, a regional network provider for higher education institutions in Southern California, developed a purpose-built Science DMZ research network. This network connects these colleges with high-capacity links to other universities in the region and provides seamless access to national research and education networks.

Intellectual Merit: Before the implementation of the Science DMZ network, researchers and the general campus community at smaller colleges shared the same network infrastructure, causing significant bottlenecks that hindered the efficiency of research activities. The introduction of a dedicated research network solved this problem by moving research-related traffic off the main campus network and onto a specialized high-capacity network. This not only freed up bandwidth for general campus users but also allowed researchers to work more efficiently with specialized tools and equipment that optimize data throughput.

The Science DMZ network was designed to take advantage of the upcoming upgrades to the Los Nettos optical network, which is the underlying infrastructure that carries data between campuses. These enhancements ensure that the network is not only capable of supporting current research needs but is also future-proofed to handle growing demands.

A participating researcher from Pomona College shared the following insight into the impact of the new infrastructure:

“The improved network infrastructure has fundamentally changed our research methodology, enabling more iterative and experimental approaches to digital heritage documentation. We can now rapidly test different processing parameters and visualization techniques, moving data seamlessly between computational resources as needed. This capability has been particularly valuable in our recent documentation of Welsh standing stones, where the ability to quickly process and evaluate different approaches has led to significant improvements in the quality and accuracy of our digital heritage representations. The Science DMZ has thus not only accelerated our research timeline but has also expanded the scope and ambition of our digital heritage preservation efforts, allowing us to create more detailed and accurate records of these invaluable prehistoric monuments for future generations.”

This statement highlights how the Science DMZ network has transformed research processes, enabling faster data processing and more accurate documentation, especially in complex projects such as digital heritage preservation.

Broader Impact: One of the key benefits of this project has been the involvement of graduate students, who gained hands-on experience with the design and deployment of the Science DMZ network. In addition to learning about advanced networking technologies, students had the opportunity to contribute to a real-world project that directly impacted their academic communities. This exposure is invaluable, as it allows students to gain practical knowledge that would not typically be available in a classroom setting.

One graduate student, a computer science major, shared his experience:

“…I am benefiting, in particular, from the work on the Science DMZ project and DWDM networking initiatives. The practical exposure to network connectivity and topology helped me better understand production network infrastructure…

… The opportunity to work on cutting-edge projects like these has inspired me to dive deeper into the field, and I’m excited about the various opportunities it opens up.”

This testimony emphasizes the impact of hands-on experience in fostering career development and expanding opportunities in the field of networking. The opportunity to work on such cutting-edge projects gives students the confidence and skills to succeed in an increasingly tech-driven world.

The scalability and flexibility of the Science DMZ network also lay the foundation for future expansion. Due to the way the network was designed, it is easy to scale up to meet future demands as research needs grow. Additionally, the network can be extended to include other interested institutions, further expanding the reach of high-performance research and education networks.

As the Science DMZ network continues to evolve, it will serve as a model for other smaller institutions looking to enhance their own research capabilities. Through this expansion, more organizations—such as the Art Center College of Design, Charles Drew University of Medicine and Science, and others—will be able to tap into these advanced networks, facilitating broader collaboration and creating new opportunities for innovation across diverse fields, from healthcare to digital arts. The project not only strengthens the research capabilities of participating colleges but also contributes to a more equitable and interconnected academic community.
